title: 112_s3598
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Robert Matava Exploitation Protection for Elder Adults Act of 2012" and includes provisions for federal prosecution of abuse and exploitation directed at elders, coordination of civil protections and criminal prosecution related to elder justice, interstate initiatives, and a GAO report. Sec. 401. GAO report to assess cost of elder abuse on Federal programs. The terms "abuse", "elder", "elder justice", "exploitation", and "neglect" are defined in the Social Security Act. "Adult protective services" include receiving reports of adult abuse, neglect, or exploitation, investigating these reports, and providing case work and services. The term "caregiver" refers to an individual responsible for the care of an elder, whether voluntarily, by contract, or through the operation of law. This includes providing compensated or uncompensated care on behalf of the elder. The term "elder abuse" includes neglect and exploitation. The term "fiduciary" refers to an individual or entity with the legal responsibility to make decisions on behalf of another individual and to act in good faith and with fairness. This includes trustees, guardians, conservators, executors, and agents under a power of attorney. The term "State" refers to various regions including States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories. It also includes individuals or entities with legal responsibility to make decisions for others, such as trustees, guardians, conservators, executors, and agents under a power of attorney. TITLE I--FEDERAL PROSECUTION OF ABUSE AND EXPLOITATION DIRECTED AT ELDERS

SEC. 101. ENHANCED PENALTY FOR TELEMARKETING AND EMAIL-MARKETING FRAUD DIRECTED AT ELDERS. Amends Chapter 113A of title 18, United States Code to include email marketing fraud directed at elders. In this chapter, telemarketing or email marketing refers to campaigns conducted to induce purchases, contest participation, donations, investments, business opportunities, loans, or fraudulent studies through interstate calls, emails, text messages, or instant messages. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of telemarketing and what it includes, such as soliciting sales through catalogs. It specifies that the solicitation should not involve contacting customers through telephone, email, text message, or electronic instant message. The curr_chunk amends regulations regarding telemarketing by including email marketing and updating references to relevant sections of the Social Security Act. SEC. 102 amends regulations to include email marketing in telemarketing fraud laws. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, shall collect statistical data on elder abuse annually from law enforcement agencies and prosecutor offices, including the number of cases referred, filed in courts, and their outcomes. Common data points among different agencies will be identified. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will collect national data on elder abuse from law enforcement agencies and prosecutor offices. The data will include the number of cases referred, filed in courts, and outcomes. Recommendations for collecting additional data will be developed. TITLE II--COORDINATION OF CIVIL PROTECTIONS AND CRIMINAL PROSECUTION AS IT RELATES TO ELDER JUSTICE

SEC. 201. MODEL STATES LAWS AND PRACTICES. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Elder Justice Coordinating Council, shall create, compile, evaluate, and disseminate materials and information to assist in investigating, prosecuting, preventing, and mitigating abuse, exploitation, and neglect of elders. The Attorney General, in collaboration with relevant authorities, is tasked with assessing and addressing the physical and psychological trauma experienced by elder abuse victims. They are also required to collect data to evaluate the effectiveness of measures to prevent elder abuse and assess the number of victims in each state. An annual report detailing the evaluation results must be published and shared with federal agencies, states, and relevant committees. The Senate and House committees are evaluating training models for law enforcement and other professionals to address elder abuse cases, evidentiary issues, and appropriate responses. The Senate and House committees are evaluating training models for law enforcement and other professionals to address elder abuse cases, evidentiary issues, and appropriate responses. They also conduct a study of laws and practices relating to elder abuse, neglect, and exploitation, including State laws and their enforcement. The curr_chunk discusses the impact of State laws on elder abuse, including definitions of abuse, neglect, and exploitation, reporting mandates, enforcement, and compliance levels. The curr_chunk reviews State laws related to elder abuse, neglect, and exploitation, including compliance levels, responses to reports, evidentiary procedures, sentencing, fiduciary laws, and laws regarding depository institutions and credit unions. The curr_chunk reviews State laws related to elder abuse, neglect, and exploitation, including prevention, reporting, civil court proceedings, fraud, programs addressing elder abuse, and other relevant laws. Additionally, the Attorney General is tasked with carrying out other duties related to elder abuse prevention. The Attorney General is responsible for carrying out duties related to enhancing the understanding, prevention, detection, and response to elder abuse. SEC. 202. CIVIL PROTECTION AND CRIMINAL PROSECUTION. Establishment of a demonstration program to provide grants to civil legal services entities for preventing and addressing elder abuse. Grants are awarded to entities committed to representing elder abuse victims and participating in efforts to combat elder abuse. Entities must be experienced nonprofit legal services providers to receive a grant. The demonstration program requires experienced nonprofit legal services providers to collaborate with various agencies, partner with criminal justice professionals, and conduct timely evaluations. A report must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of program completion, including results and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Attorney General for fiscal years 2013 through 2017 to carry out the program. TITLE III--INTERSTATE INITIATIVES

SEC. 301. Interstate agreements and compacts allow 2 or more States to cooperate in promoting elder safety and well-being and enforcing laws.

SEC. 302. Recommendations on interstate communication. The Executive Director of the State Justice Institute, in consultation with State or local aging, social, and human services and law enforcement agencies, shall submit legislative proposals to Congress on facilitating interstate agreements and compacts. The Comptroller General of the United States, in consultation with relevant agencies, will publish a report assessing the financial cost to the Federal Government from elder abuse and exploitation within a year of this Act's enactment.
